Key Arguments: It is inconsistent with fundamental freedoms of speech and communication under international human and political rights.
The bill grants excessive power to unelected bureaucrats without transparency or accountability.
The definition of 'harm' in the bill is vague.
There is no mechanism to hold digital service providers liable for excessive policing of legitimate speech.
The exclusion of government-authorized content from the regime is hypocritical.
The bill breaches privacy by compelling digital platforms to provide information.
There is insufficient accountability and oversight for misuse of censorship powers.
The penalties for non-compliance are excessive and may lead to over-censorship.
Notable Quotes: The idea that a government body, or any organisation for that matter, can independently determine what is misinformation or disinformation is in line with Communist or other totalitarian style governments.
The Bill is inconsistent with fundamental freedoms of speech and communication under international human and political rights.
The exclusion of government-authorised content from this censorship regime is hypocritical, one rule for government and another rule for Australians in what they can say.
